label: A_hP3_152_a-001
title: $\gamma$-Se ($A8$) Structure
comments:
There are a variety of naming conventions for selenium: 
 (Cherin, 1967) refers to this structure as ``trigonal selenium.'' (Donohue, 1982) refers to it as the $\alpha$-Se structure, calling what we designate \href{current_web_home_dir/A_mP64_14_16e-001}{$\alpha$-Se} and \href{current_web_home_dir/A_mP32_14_8e-001}{$\beta$-Se ($A_{l}$)} as ``monoclinic $\alpha$''  and ``monoclinic $\beta$,'' respectively. 
 When $x=1/3$ this reduces to the \href{current_web_home_dir/A_hR1_166_a-001}{$A_{i}$ ($\beta$-Po)} or \href{current_web_home_dir/A_hR1_166_a-002}{$A10$ ($\alpha$-Hg)} structure. \begin{itemize} \item If, in addition, $c=\sqrt{6} \, a$, then the structure becomes \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cF4_225_a-001}{fcc ($A1$)}. \item On the other hand, if $c=\sqrt{3/2} \, a$, then the structure becomes \href{current_web_home_dir/A_cP1_221_a-001}{simple cubic ($A_{h}$)}. \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 This structure can also be found in the enantiomorphic space group $P3_{2}12$ \#153.
